titleStmt.title: M73. [The Reader? "Elizabethan clothes"]. Holograph fragment, undated. 1p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: Possible fragment of 'The Reader' not initially catalogued as such.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Elizabethan clothes have had too much attention from
the historical novelist, & too little from the
psychologist. What [feelings?] [diverse?] did they represent
was gratified by their an extraordinary display? The
histories of men. What were they being was behind

l.del: the discomfort of this [tortuous?] cloaks, their
loops of pearls, their stiff ruffs there their

p.l: enormous expense & discomfort? to

l.del: the clothes. They drew They are [fir?] in fancy dress.

p.l: cladding men & women as if [in?] a fancy
dress party. The cost was great, & the
they must have been acting some part
There must have been some [other?]presence on them
to induce them that forced them to
this extraordinary display?- some meaning
that ordained - not some the cost was
great; the discomfort appalling: But
Inwardly the must have dread to [proclaim?] some
device –– to appear make visible something
that was of some body. The old
clothes in the museums are part an
attempt at saying proving something: stating something
somebody some view of life wh. which is foreign, a
[product?] perhaps: an affirmation –
Hammill 11/17/58
